sections: In June, the Biden administration made an announcement that irked fossil fuel companies and utilities: Federal regulators would begin reinstating a rule empowering states and tribes to protect waterways against pollution from energy development.
Now, a mere three months later, the Biden White House just
its support for a secret deal designed to expedite approval of those energy projects, potentially helping oil and gas conglomerates steamroll local opposition to new pipelines near water supplies.
The apparent shift in priorities comes as energy companies have

into Democratic campaign coffers, and as former staffers for top Democrats are lobbying for fossil fuel clients. One of the largest natural gas pipeline companies is now celebrating the Biden administration‚Äôs ‚Äútailwinds‚Äù for the fossil fuel industry amid the worsening climate crisis.

The situation has scrambled congressional politics: Some Democrats who once attacked the Trump administration‚Äôs rollback of longstanding environmental protections are now backing the secret deal that could make that rollback permanent.
The tension between President Joe Biden‚Äôs environmental regulators and the ‚Äúpermitting reform‚Äù side deal reflects the outsized power of Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.), Congress‚Äôs

of fossil fuel industry campaign cash. The West Virginia coal magnate conditioned his Senate vote for the Inflation Reduction Act on an agreement to separately pass a ‚Äúpermitting reform‚Äù bill that could make it more difficult for communities to use the Clean Water Act and other environmental laws to protect their water resources from new energy infrastructure.

‚ÄúThis is a reckless piece of legislation that would undermine President Biden‚Äôs climate goals, as well as efforts within the administration to protect waterways and states‚Äô rights to protect their waterways from damaging fossil fuel projects,‚Äù Jim Walsh, policy director at Food and Water Watch, told
from drilling fluid leaks, large removals of soil and sediment, erosion, or other types of disruption. For instance, just last month the pipeline company Energy Transfer
of criminal charges for massive water contamination caused by the construction of its Mariner East natural gas pipeline network in Pennsylvania.

Additionally, when it comes to oil infrastructure, once pipelines are constructed, leaks and spills also pose a threat to water supplies: Since 1986, pipeline accidents have been spilling more than 3 million gallons a year in the United States, according to
compiled by the Center for Biological Diversity.

The Biden administration has spent months attempting to resurrect local authority under the 50-year-old Clean Water Act in the wake of President Donald Trump‚Äôs efforts to dismantle it ‚Äî a move bolstered by the Supreme Court this spring.
That saga began in 2020. That year, as

of fossil fuel industry cash flooded into Republican coffers, Trump‚Äôs Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) limited the power of states and tribes to enforce Section 401 of the Clean Water Act, which was written to ensure new energy infrastructure would not violate local water pollution laws. Trump‚Äôs new rules were
opposition from state legislatures to fossil fuel projects, after a trio of such projects were blocked or delayed in New York, Washington, and Oregon.
A slew of states and environmental groups sued to block the Trump rule from taking effect, and in 2021, a district court in California
. But this spring, the Supreme Court
Before the Trump changes, ‚ÄúSection 401 was used all the time to attach conditions to projects,‚Äù Patrick Hunter, senior attorney at the Southern Environmental Law Center, told
‚ÄúIt is rare that it is used to veto anything ‚Äî but it is common that it is used to add conditions to a project to ensure that water quality is protected.‚Äù
In June, Biden‚Äôs EPA proposed a new rule, supported by
, that would return authority to states and tribes to impose conditions on federal permits for infrastructure projects if they would impact local waterways.

‚ÄúFor 50 years, the Clean Water Act has protected water resources that are essential to thriving communities, vibrant ecosystems, and sustainable economic growth,‚Äù said Michael Regan, head of the EPA, in a

on the proposed rule. ‚ÄúEPA‚Äôs proposed rule builds on this foundation by empowering states, territories, and Tribes to use Congressionally granted authority to protect precious water resources while supporting much-needed infrastructure projects that create jobs and bolster our economy.‚Äù

Hunter noted that Biden‚Äôs proposed rule is an even-handed way to ‚Äúrequire whoever is building the project to provide more information up front with their certification request ‚Äî so that actually has an opportunity to make things run more efficiently.‚Äù
That is apparently unacceptable to the powerful corporate lobbies that went to work to try to stop the initiative.

Natural gas pipeline companies submitted scathing comments on the rule, arguing it would give states and tribes too much power to slow down or block projects. They didn‚Äôt mince their words in pointing out that the rule could interfere with their ambitions to ramp up natural gas production, especially for export to Europe.
The two primary industry trade groups, the Interstate Natural Gas Association of America and the American Gas Association, submitted an
with suggested changes to Biden‚Äôs proposed rule.

‚ÄúThe 2020 Certification Rule was EPA‚Äôs first update to the Agency‚Äôs Section 401 regulations in nearly 50 years,‚Äù the comment letter said, in reference to the Trump rule. In reference to the Section 401 regulations that had been in place since the 1970s, the letter later continued, ‚ÄúUnder the prior regime, states blocked energy infrastructure projects that were in the public interest of both individual states and the nation as a whole for reasons unrelated to water quality, such as for the project‚Äôs perceived climate change impacts or general opposition to fossil fuels.‚Äù
A coalition of utility companies, including NextEra Energy, one of the developers of the Mountain Valley Pipeline in West Virginia and a
the EPA to retain key components of the Trump rule.
Williams Companies, the largest natural gas supplier in the U.S., argued in a
that the proposed rule would interfere with Biden‚Äôs efforts to ramp up natural gas exports to Europe in the face of dwindling supply from Russia.

‚ÄúPresident Biden made robust energy supply commitments to the European Commission that will require a rapid expansion of our domestic energy infrastructure,‚Äù the company wrote to the EPA. ‚ÄúIf the United States is to support the natural gas supply commitment President Biden made to our European Allies, the EPA must rescind this Proposed Rule and propose a rule that better aligns with the commitments and goals set forth by President Biden.‚Äù

That pipeline was originally held up by the very Clean Water Act provisions that Biden‚Äôs EPA rule aims to restore, as the Natural Gas Supply Association, a lobbying group for natural gas companies, said in a

To be sure, the leaked draft of the pipeline deal differs from the Biden EPA rule in a number of ways, including by adjusting the amount of time states and tribes have to certify permits. While the timing issues are technical ‚Äî they deal, for example, with when the clock starts on the one-year period that states and tribes have to certify permits ‚Äî the implications are huge for projects, and a fierce battle is now underway in Congress.

Following The Money And Lobbying Trail
All of the lobbying and policy zig-zagging has happened amid a flood of cash from the energy industry.
In the 2022 election cycle, Democratic candidates and committees have vacuumed in more than $13 million from donors in the
industries. Schumer, Manchin, and Democrats‚Äô Senate and House campaign committees have together accepted

As that lobbying blitz has intensified, some Democratic lawmakers who lambasted Trump‚Äôs repeal of the original Clean Water Act rule and praised Biden‚Äôs proposed rule are now backing the still-secret permitting reform deal.

‚ÄúThe Clean Water Act quite clearly gives states, territories, and Tribes the ability to protect their water quality when projects are permitted or licensed,‚Äù said Sen. Tom Carper (D-Del.), chairman of the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works,
on the proposed Biden rule. ‚ÄúI commend Administrator Regan and the technical experts at EPA for taking a prudent step to help these governments act to address local water quality.‚Äù
